Select the "Local Files" tab4. Click "Verify integrity of game cache"This has been known to easily fix the "Failed to find steam" error. If the issue persists then it is recommended you try these steps:1. Open the Start Menu, right click "Computer", and select "Properties".2. From the column on the left of the new panel, select "Advanced System Settings".3. From the new dialogue, press "Environment Variables..." (at the bottom of the "Advanced" panel, just above "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply").4. In the top half of the newly opened dialogue (User variables) if there is:a - no existing entry for PATH, use "New..." to add it (Variable Name: PATH, Variable Value: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam -- i.e. wherever you have Steam installed).b - already an entry for PATH, use "Edit..." to add ;C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam (or wherever your Steam is installed) at the end of the existing value. (Note the semi-colon to separate the value that was already there from the new bit with the Steam path.)5. Press "OK"6. Log off and log on again. You should now be able to run the Steam titles without problems.If you have further issues I suggest you contact Steam Support as there may be issues with your Steam Client.After that the game will start, but it can be really slow ( about 1 FPS), try than setting at highest possible graphic settings and check box called 'User Direct3D'. It starts on fullscrean, but it is slightly smaller than your whole monitor, so it should allow you to run it and enjoy that great game!

The core features of this game - amazing visuals and simplified strategy part, countless hours of fun!++Visuals - beautiful character arts, cool mobs models, brutal heroes and colorful landscapes - everything perfectly mixed to create an amazing feeling of a magical journey to the land of Elves and Demons! The depth of this game don't come from adding more and more races and units and what not, like Heroes III does, just one new gameplay mechanic gets introduced, and the entire balance of everything shifts, because everything is interconnected. I was shocked, that i needed special character to capture territory, i need special skill to equip ancient artifacts, if i dig up an item from somewhere, i don't just know how to use it. This game borders with RPGs as well. I was playing and I noticed a grave. I clicked on it, and it told me who killed who on that place. Attention to detail. Today we will have huge particle explosion and nothing else. This game keeps record on who have you killed and where. I love this kind of stuff. So well done, so well implemented, all intertwine together to create this beautiful game. I can't believe no other game tried even, to create that kind of gameplay. 10 years old, still unmatched.+ beautiful visuals+ deep complex rewarding gameplay+ I need to give another point to the gameplay. 												Fantastic HoMM-style turn-based strategy RPG built around Norse mythology marred by some poor game design choices. There's great variety between the races and each has their own campaign, with each faction having a distinct style. The terrain control mechanic is a great visual representation of your area control but I find it downplayed in many missions because of a turn limit or boss rush. Hero customization is diverse and has more options than HoMM but they are slower to level up. Although it has aged poorly, this is a great HoMM alternative that is worth checking out if you're a fan of strategy games.

												Playing Disciples II is the Turn-Based Strategy equivalent of sitting at home buzzsawing through a huge bag of greasy, salty potato chips. I know for a fact that there are way better things I could be doing.  I also know that what I'm eating has next to no meaningfull nutritional content. They don't even taste especially good, and I'm getting bored and frustrated and only eating out of habit.  So why the hell am I still eating?!  Well, the game does look pretty, in that early-Rennaissance-variant Grimdark(TM) way. It also offers reasonably steady advancement in power, and a few head-scratching tactical challenges. Mostly, though, it comes down to grinding, hoarding and (save) scumming. Grinding: learn to recognize the fights your troops can survive and still gain meaningful XP from, keep hitting as fast as you safely can till your dudes gain a few levels and a commensurate capacity to curb-stomp anything other than the final battle (troop upgrade levels determine any fight that hasn't been pre-determined by magic or thief spam: a difference of one level guarantees the higher-tier army will win, two or more guarantees a massacre.)  Hoarding: get mines and mana nodes. Money is necessary for Grinding, since the buildings needed to upgrade your troops get hella expensive at tiers 4 and 5, while mana powers the spells that tilt combats. Use as little mana and money as needed to keep your troops alive and upgrading, then when the map's big bad comes into view burn it to guarantee a win. Cast every spell you can, twice if you can, send mobs of Thieves to soften up fortified armies, send disposable heroes leading quick-firing ranged units, you get the idea. Scumming occurs when those first two don't work, or are derailed by unforseen circumstances, which becomes more common as you climb the difficulty levels. The couple of different auto-save functions make this slightly less irritating. The end result is a game where fights can largely be predicted in advance (no tactical genius can offset spell bombardment or superior forces), and strategy between fights is largely a matter of trial and error. You can let it eat up a ton of time, or you could go play something more interesting. (Yes, I know this review sounds like a three-hundred-pound couch potato telling his kids to exercise. Remember, folks: hypocrisy is the debt vice pays to virtue.)

												Although a lot of these reviews claim this game is broken and unplayable on Win7, that isn't the case, as a few minor tweaks (compatibility, run as admin., etc.) will make the game run fine. However, the game is by far one of the most unbalanced and least enjoyable games I have ever played. Anyone who has ever played the Might and Magic series will certainly be familiar with a high level of difficulty, but in that series a thorough grasp of the game mechanics combined with  a few false starts as you acquaint yourself with the lay of land will ultimately allow you to complete the missions. To take another example, the excellent Age of Wonders series (my personal benchmark for strategy/rpg excellence) is often said to be punishing, but the fact is once you learn all the game's tools, it's a rich and highly rewarding experience and there's no reason why you can't complete missions in fine fashion.Disciples 2, on the other hand, is simply an exercise in masochism. Yes, the missions can be completed, but not without an excessive and highly frustrating amount of bloodletting, dying, reviving, etc., as from the start you will find that EVERY enemy on the map is stronger than you. Nor does it get better, as your character's progression -- should you be fortunate enough to carry one from one mission to the next -- is minimal at best and hardly matters compared to the strength of the monsters. Buffers offer only the most marginal of enhancements to your troops' stats, costly spells bestow laughable gains (10 fire damage to 300 HP monsters, oh boy), and hard-won battles are rewarded by the most modest and least consequential of loot drops.It's only been from sheer stubbornness that I've persisted to the second mission (halfway through and looking bleak, overpowered beasts everywhere), but frankly, aside from the so-so graphics and music, this game offers precious little in the way of enjoyment.

												This was one of my absolute favourites as a baby gamer. What caused me to responde so much about this game is its atmosphere: its high fantasy, decadent design, the beautiful beautiful isometric landscapes, the sombre, solemn music, the epic quality of the story. I recall the sheer pleasure in immersing myself in this dark world where there are no good sides and everything is permeated by this sort of gritty grandeur. Gameplay-wise, it is very similar to the Heroes of Might and Magic titles, with a decisively steeper difficulty curve. Resource management is particularly tricky in this one, especially once you get to play the biggest maps. The different factions are all very well characterised not only in terms of design and contextualization, but also in gameplay. Every single one of them plays different strategies best: the Legion of the Damned has excellent nukers and favours brief fights, the Undead Hordes deploys excellent crowd control, the Empire thrives in longer fights combining sustain and utility, etc.Also their power spikes - provided by mainly by unlocking units and spells - happen at different times for each faction, providing added layer of complexity to the gameplay. To know when and why invest to accelerate towards said power spikes is absolutely key if you want to play the highest difficulty level - definitely the most rewarding.Added perk: an excellent scenario editor. I had the time of my life crafting from scratch epic campaigns for my brother and friends using its gorgeous graphics and the dumb-proof interface. A wonderful experience.

												This was one of my absolute favourites as a baby gamer. What caused me to responde so much about this game is its atmosphere: its high fantasy, decadent design, the beautiful beautiful isometric landscapes, the sombre, solemn music, the epic quality of the story. I recall the sheer pleasure in immersing myself in this dark world where there are no good sides and everything is permeated by this sort of gritty grandeur. Gameplay-wise, it is very similar to the Heroes of Might and Magic titles, with a decisively steeper difficulty curve. Resource management is particularly tricky in this one, especially once you get to play the biggest maps. The different factions are all very well characterised not only in terms of design and contextualization, but also in gameplay. Every single one of them plays different strategies best: the Legion of the Damned has excellent nukers and favours brief fights, the Undead Hordes deploys excellent crowd control, the Empire thrives in longer fights combining sustain and utility, etc.Also their power spikes - provided by mainly by unlocking units and spells - happen at different times for each faction, providing added layer of complexity to the gameplay. To know when and why invest to accelerate towards said power spikes is absolutely key if you want to play the highest difficulty level - definitely the most rewarding.Added perk: an excellent scenario editor. I had the time of my life crafting from scratch epic campaigns for my brother and friends using its gorgeous graphics and the dumb-proof interface. A wonderful experience.

												Disciples II is strongly reminiscent of Heroes of Might and Magic III mixed with the Ogre Battle series of games, and the mix is succesfully engagingThose familiar with HoMMIII should feel comfortable with the turn based play, isometric map, resources, town building and creature tiers. The primary difference is in the combat.As in Ogre Battle, combat takes place between squads that meet up on the map. Rather than stacks of creatures, each member of a squad is a single creature with a health bar. A number of rules dictate the squad composition: A squad has a limited number of slots, a large creatures may take up multiple slots, some units can only attack from the front row, others from both. To this end it's greatly engaging experimenting with squad composition and placement, building countersquads, attrition squads, and so on. I recommend this to fans of either of the two games it resembles, or simply fantasy TBS's in general
